Literature Review: Iron is an essential micronutrient that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including oxygen transport, DNA synthesis, and cellular metabolism. However, emerging evidence suggests that excessive iron accumulation in tissues can contribute to the development and progression of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). This literature review aims to explore the complex relationship between iron and the pathophysiology of diabetes, focusing on the mechanisms by which iron affects insulin secretion, insulin resistance, and hepatic gluconeogenesis.Iron overload has been associated with an increased risk of T2DM in numerous epidemiological studies. Fernández-Real et al. (2002) demonstrated that elevated serum ferritin levels, a marker of iron stores, were positively correlated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of T2DM in healthy individuals. This association was further supported by a large prospective study conducted by Jiang et al. (2004), which found that higher iron intake, particularly from heme sources, was associated with a significantly increased risk of T2DM in women.The impact of iron on insulin secretion has been a subject of intense research. Beta cells in the pancreas are particularly susceptible to iron-induced oxidative stress due to their low antioxidant capacity. Cooksey et al. (2004) showed that iron overload in pancreatic islets led to decreased insulin secretion and beta cell dysfunction in animal models. The authors proposed that iron-catalyzed free radical formation could damage beta cell mitochondria, leading to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion.Insulin resistance, a hallmark of T2DM, is also influenced by iron status. Adipose tissue plays a crucial role in glucose homeostasis, and iron accumulation in adipocytes has been shown to alter their function. Gabrielsen et al. (2012) demonstrated that iron overload in adipocytes led to decreased adiponectin production and increased expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines, contributing to systemic insulin resistance. Furthermore, iron accumulation in skeletal muscle has been associated with impaired glucose uptake and insulin signaling, as shown by Huang et al. (2011) in their study of iron-overloaded mice.The liver, a major site of iron storage and glucose metabolism, is another key player in the iron-diabetes relationship. Increased hepatic iron stores have been linked to insulin resistance and increased gluconeogenesis. McClain et al. (2006) found that iron overload in hepatocytes led to increased oxidative stress and activation of stress-responsive transcription factors, resulting in impaired insulin signaling and enhanced gluconeogenesis. This finding was corroborated by Dongiovanni et al. (2013), who demonstrated that iron depletion in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease improved insulin sensitivity and glucose tolerance.The role of hepcidin, the master regulator of systemic iron homeostasis, has gained attention in recent years. Hepcidin production is increased in response to inflammation and iron overload, leading to decreased iron absorption and sequestration of iron in macrophages. Aigner et al. (2014) showed that hepcidin levels were elevated in patients with T2DM and correlated with markers of insulin resistance. The authors proposed that chronic low-grade inflammation in T2DM could lead to hepcidin-mediated iron dysregulation, further exacerbating metabolic dysfunction.Genetic factors also play a role in the iron-diabetes relationship. Hereditary hemochromatosis, a genetic disorder characterized by iron overload, has been associated with an increased risk of T2DM. Ellervik et al. (2007) conducted a meta-analysis of studies examining the prevalence of diabetes in hemochromatosis patients and found a significantly higher risk of diabetes compared to the general population. This finding highlights the importance of iron homeostasis in maintaining metabolic health.The molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of iron on diabetes pathophysiology are diverse and complex. Iron-induced oxidative stress appears to be a central theme, with reactive oxygen species (ROS) playing a key role in beta cell dysfunction, insulin resistance, and hepatic gluconeogenesis. Additionally, iron has been shown to interfere with insulin signaling pathways and alter the expression of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism. Simcox and McClain (2013) proposed that iron might act as a metabolic regulator by influencing cellular energy metabolism and fuel choice, potentially through its effects on mitochondrial function and hypoxia-inducible factors.Understanding the intricate relationship between iron and diabetes has important implications for both prevention and treatment strategies. Iron chelation therapy has shown promise in improving insulin sensitivity and glucose tolerance in patients with iron overload disorders. Conversely, iron supplementation in iron-deficient individuals should be approached with caution, as excessive iron intake may increase the risk of T2DM in susceptible populations.In conclusion, the growing body of evidence linking iron to the pathophysiology of diabetes underscores the importance of maintaining optimal iron homeostasis for metabolic health. Future research should focus on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying iron's effects on metabolism and exploring potential therapeutic interventions targeting iron-related pathways in the prevention and treatment of T2DM.
